speaker: parent
content: Once upon a time, there was a little house way out in the country. She was a pretty little house, and she was strong and well built. The man who built her so well said, “This little house shall never be sold, for gold or silver, and she will live to see our great-great-grandchildren's, great-great-grandchildren living in her.”

speaker: parent
content: The little house was very happy as she sat on the hill, and watched the countryside around her. She watched the sunrise in the morning, and she watched the sunset in the evening.

speaker: parent
content: Like one for each hour. Day followed day...

speaker: parent
content: Oh, that's more than a day.

speaker: parent
content: Yeah. Day followed day, each one a little different from the one before, but the little house stayed just the same. In the night, she watched the moon grow from a thin new moon to a full moon, then back again to a thin old moon.

speaker: parent
content: 56. And when there was no moon, she watched the stars. Way off in the distance, she could see the lights of the city. The little house was curious about the city, and wondered what it would be like to live there. Time passed quickly for the little house as she watched the countryside slowly change with the seasons. In the spring, when the days grew longer, and the sun warmer, she waited for the first robin to return from the south. She watched the grass turn green, she watched the buds on the trees swell, and the apple tree burst into blossom. She watched the children playing in the brook.

speaker: parent
content: In the long summer days, she sat in the sun, and watched the trees cover themselves with leaves, and the white daisy's cover the hill. She watched the gardens grow, and she watched the apples turn red and ripen, and she watched children swimming in the pool. In the fall, when the days grew shorter, the nights colder, she watched the first frost turn the leaves to bright yellow, and orange, and red. She watched the harvest gathered and the apples picked. She watched the children going back to school. In the winter, when the nights were long, and the days were short, and the countryside covered with snow, she watched the children coasting, and skating.

speaker: parent
content: Year followed year, the apple trees grew old, and new ones were planted. The children grew up and went away to the city, and now at night, the lights of the city seem brighter and closer. One day, the little house was so surprised to see a horseless carriage coming down the winding country road. Do you know what a horseless carriage is?
question: Do you know what a horseless carriage is

speaker: child
content: No.

speaker: parent
content: What do you think we drive in? Car? There are no horses. Anyway, pretty soon, there were more of them on the road and fewer carriages pulled by horses. Pretty soon, along came some surveyors and surveyed a line in front of the little house. Pretty soon, along came a steam shovel, and dug a road through the hill covered with daisy's. Then some trucks came and dumped big stones on the road. Then some trucks with little stones. Then some trucks with tar, and sand. And finally a steam roller came, and rolled it all smooth, and the road was done.
question: What do you think we drive in::: Car

speaker: parent
content: Now the little house watched the trucks and automobiles going back and forth to the city. Gasoline stations, road side stands, and small houses followed the new road. Everyone and everything moved faster now than before. More roads were made and the countryside was divided into lots. More houses and bigger houses. Apartment houses and tenement houses. Schools, stores, and garages spread over the land, and crowded around the little house. No one wanted to live in her, and take care of her anymore. She couldn't be sold for silver gold, so she just stayed there and watched.

speaker: parent
content: Now it was not so quiet and peaceful at night. Now the lights of the city were bright, and very close, and the street light shown all night. “This must be living in the city,” thought the little house, and didn't know whether she liked it or not. She missed the fields of daisy's, and the apple trees dancing in the moon light. Pretty soon, there were trolley cars going back and forth in front of the little house. They went back and forth all day, and part of the night. Everyone seemed to be very busy, and everyone seemed to be in a hurry.

speaker: parent
content: Pretty soon, there was an elevated train going back and forth above the little house. The air was filled with dust and smoke, and the noise was so loud that it shook the little house. Now she couldn't tell when spring came, or summer, or fall, or winter. It all seemed about the same. Pretty soon, there was a subway going back and forth under the little house. She couldn't see it but she could feel and hear it. People were moving faster and faster.

speaker: child
content: There's 3 subways.

speaker: parent
content: 3 subways? Where?
question: 3 subways::: Where

speaker: child
content: I mean, 3 trains.

speaker: parent
content: Yeah.

speaker: parent
content: Oh my goodness, that's a lot of trains.

speaker: child
content: That's a elevators.

speaker: parent
content: Yes.

speaker: child
content: One, I like that.

speaker: parent
content: Yeah.

speaker: child
content: I think...

speaker: parent
content: It seems very efficient.

speaker: child
content: I really like that. I think she should stay, because that's like cool.

speaker: parent
content: I think it's cool too, but some people don't like city, so, and trains.

speaker: parent
content: People were moving faster and faster. No one noticed that little house anymore, they hurried by without a glance. Pretty soon, they tore down the apartment houses and tenement houses around the little house, and started digging big cellars, one on each side. The steam shovels, dug down 3 stories on one side, and 4 stories on the other side. Pretty soon, they started building up. They built up 25 stories on one side, and 35 stories on the other. Now the little house only saw the sun at noon, and didn't see the moon or starts at night at all, because the lights of the city were too bright. She didn't like living in the city. At night, she used to dream of the country, and the fields of daisy's, and the apple trees dancing in the moon light.

speaker: parent
content: The little house was very sad and lonely. Her paint was cracked and dirty. Her windows were broken, and her shutters were hung crookedly. She looked shabby, though she was just as good a house as ever underneath. Then one fine morning in spring, along came the great...

speaker: child
content: Where's the one under.

speaker: parent
content: There she is... [crosstalk 00:08:48] Oh, the other trains? I don't know, maybe, oh it's cause it's underground, you can't see it unless they show you. And they're just showing you what's above ground.
question: [crosstalk 00:08:48] Oh, the other trains

speaker: child
content: Oh.

speaker: parent
content: Along came the great-great-granddaughter of the man who built the little house so well. She saw the shabby little house, but she didn't hurry by. There was something about the little house that made her stop and look again. She said to her husband, “That little house looks just like the little house my grandmother lived in when she was a little girl. Only, that little house, was way out in the country on a hill covered with daisy's, and apple trees growing around.” They found out it was the same, very same house, so they went to the movers to see if the little house could be moved. The movers looked at the little house all over, and said, “Sure! This house is as good as ever! She's built so well, we could mover her anyway... anywhere.” So they jacked up the little house that she...

speaker: child
content: This picture looks, looks all the same.

speaker: parent
content: Yeah, well, sometimes it's the same one twice in a row.

speaker: parent
content: Traffic was held up for hours, as they slowly moved her out of the city. I'm sure people trying to get to work loved that. At first, the little house was frightened, but after she got used to it, she really liked it. They rolled along the big road, and they rolled along the little roads, until they were way out in the country. When the little house saw the green grass, and heard the birds singing, she didn't feel sad anymore. They went along, and along...

speaker: child
content: The last one was spring. Did she notice spring now?
question: Did she notice spring now

speaker: parent
content: But they couldn't seem to find the right place. They tried the little house here, and they tried her there, they finally saw a little hill in the middle of a field, and apple trees growing around. “There!”, said the great-great-granddaughter...

question: Is it summer or spring

question: I don't know, what do you think

speaker: parent

speaker: parent
content: “Yes it is!”, said the little house to herself. A cellar was dug on top of the hill, and slowly they moved the house from the road to the hill. The windows, and shutters were fixed, and once again, they painted her a lovely shade of pink. As the little house settled down on her new foundation, she smiled happily. Once again, she could watch the sun, and moon, and stars. Once again she could watch spring, and summer, and fall, and winter, come and go. Once again she was lived in, and taken care of.

speaker: parent
content: Never again would she be curious about the city. Never again would she want to live there. The stars twinkled above her, a new moon was coming up. It was spring, and all was quiet and peaceful in the country. The end.

speaker: parent
content: The Lorax? Okay.
question: The Lorax

speaker: parent
content: At the far end of town, where the grickle grass grows, and the wind smells slow and sour when it blows, and no birds ever sing excepting old crows, is the street of the lifted Lorax.

speaker: parent
content: Something to sleep, the grickle grass some people say, if you look deep enough, you can still see today. Where the Lorax once stood, just as long as it could, before somebody lifted the Lorax away. What was the Lorax? And why was it there? And why was it lifted and taken somewhere? From the far end of town, where the grickle grass grows, the old Once-ler still lives here. Ask him, he knows.
question: What was the Lorax::: And why was it there::: And why was it lifted and taken somewhere

speaker: parent
content: You won't see the Once-ler, don't knock at his door, he stays in his lerkim, on top of his store. He lurks in his lerkim, cold under the roof, where he makes his own clothes out of miff-muffered moof. And on special nights in August, he peeks out of shutters, and sometimes he speaks, and tell how the Lorax was lifted away. He'll tell you perhaps, if you're willing to pay.

speaker: parent
content: On the end of a rope, he lets down a tin pail, and you have to toss in 15 cents, and a nail, and the shell of a great-great-great-grandfather snail. Then he pulls up the pail, and makes a most careful count, to see if you've paid him the proper amount. Then he hides what you paid him, away in his snuvv, his secret strange hole, in his gruvvulouse glove.

speaker: parent
content: Then he grunts, “I will call you by whisper-ma-phone, for the secrets I tell you are for your ears alone." Slupp Down slupps the whisper-ma-phone to your ear, and the old Once-ler's whispers are not very clear, since they have to come down through a snergelly hose, and he sounds as if he had smallish bees up his nose. “Now I'll tell you,” he says with his teeth sounding gray, "how the Lorax got lifted and taken away. It all started back such a long, long time back. Way back in the days when the grass was still green, and the pond was still wet, and the clouds were still clean, and the song of the swomee-swans rang out in space. One morning I came to this glorious place, and I first saw the trees, the truffula trees. The bright-colored tufts of the truffula trees. Miles after mile in the fresh morning breeze."

speaker: parent
content: "And under the trees, I saw brown bar-ba-loots frisking about in their bar-ba-loot suits, and they played in the shade, and ate truffula fruits. From the rippulous pond came the comfortable sound of the humming-fish humming while splashing around. But those trees, those trees, those truffula trees. All my life I've been searching for trees such as these. The touch of their tufts was much softer then silk, and they had the sweet smell of fresh butterfly milk. I felt a great leaping of joy in my heart, I knew just what I'd do, I unloaded my cart."

speaker: parent
content: "In no time at all, I had built a small shop. Then I chopped down a truffula tree with one chop, and with great skillful skill, and with great speedy speed, I took the soft tuft, I knitted a thneed."

speaker: parent
content: "The instant I'd finished, I'd heard a ga-zump, I looked. I saw something pop out of the stump, of the tree I'd chopped down. It was sort of a man. Describe him? That's hard, I don't know if I can. He was shortish, and oldish, and brownish, and mossy, and he spoke with a voice that was sharpish and bossy."

speaker: parent
content: “Mister!,” he said, with a saw dusty sneeze, “I am the Lorax, I speak for the trees! I speak for the trees, for the trees have no tongues, and I'm asking you sir at the top of my lungs!” He was very upset as he shouted, and puffed. “What's that thing you've made out of my truffula tuft?”
question: “What's that thing you've made out of my truffula tuft

speaker: parent
content: “Look Lorax,” I said, “there's no card for alarm, I just chopped one tree, I'm doing no harm. I'm being quite useful. This thing is a thneed! A thneed's a fine something that all people need. It's a shirt, it's a sock, it's a glove, it's a hat, but it has other uses, yes, far beyond that. You can use it for carpets, for pillows, for sheets, or curtains, or covers for bicycle seats.”

speaker: parent
content: The Lorax said, “ Sir, you are crazy with greed. There's no one on earth who would buy that fool thneed!”

speaker: parent
content: But the very next minute, I proved he was wrong. For just at that minute, a chap came along, and he thought that the thneed I had knitted was great, and he happily bought if for $3.98. I laughed at the Lorax, “You poor stupid guy, you never can tell what some people will buy.”

speaker: parent
content: “I repeat!” Said the Lorax, “I speak for the trees,”

speaker: parent
content: “I'm busy!” I told him, “Shut up, if you please.”

speaker: parent
content: I rushed across the room, and at no time at all, built a radio phone. I put in a quick call. I called on my brothers, and uncles, and aunts, and I said, “listen here, here's a wonderful chance for the whole Once-ler family to get mighty rich. Get over here fast, take the road to North Nitch, turn left at Weehawken, sharp right at South Stitch.”

speaker: parent
content: And in no time at all, in the factory I built, the whole Once-ler family was working full tilt. They were all knitting thneed's, busy as bees to the sound of the chopping of truffula trees. Then, oh baby, oh, how my business did grow. Now chopping one tree at a time was too slow. So I quickly invented my super-axe-hacker, which whacked off 4 truffula trees in once smacker. We were making thneeds 4 times as fast as before, and that Lorax, he didn't show up anymore.

speaker: parent
content: But the next week, he knocked on my new office door. He snapped, “I am the Lorax, who speaks for the trees, which you seem to be chopping as fast as you please. But I'm also in charge of the brown bar-ba-loots, who played in the shade in their bar-ba-loot suits, and happily lived eating truffula fruits. Now, thanks to your hacking my trees to the ground, there's not enough truffula fruit to go 'round. And my poor bar-ba-loots are all getting the crummies because they have gas and no food in their tummies. They loved living here, but I can't let them stay. They'll have to find food, and I hope that they may."

speaker: child
content: It looks, smaller, and smaller.

speaker: parent
content: Yeah, it does.

speaker: child
content: Why?
question: Why

speaker: parent
content: Because he's chopping down all the trees.

speaker: child
content: What's these? There?
question: What's these::: There

speaker: parent
content: The truffula... 'cause they're getting further away.

speaker: child
content: Oh, because the smaller ones are going food?
question: Oh, because the smaller ones are going food

speaker: parent
content: That could be too.

speaker: child
content: They look really cute.

speaker: parent
content: They do, but they look really sad.

speaker: parent
content: “Good luck boys!”, he cried, as he sent them away. I the Once-ler felt sad as I watched them all go, but business is business, and business must grow regaurdless of crummies, and tummies you know. I meant no harm, I most truly did not, but I had to grow bigger, so bigger I got. I biggered my factory, I biggered my roads, I biggered my wagons, I biggered the loads of the thneeds I shipped out. I was shipping them forth, to the south, to the east, to the west, to the north. I went right on biggering, selling more thneeds, and I biggered my money, which everyone needs.

speaker: parent
content: Then again he came back, I was fixing some pipes, when that old nuisance Lorax came back with more gripes. “I am the Lorax!”, he coughed, and he whiffed. He sneezed, and he snuffled, he snargled, he sniffed. “Once-ler!”, he cried, with a cruffulous croak, “Once-ler, you're making such smogulous smoke! My poor swomee-swans, why they can't sing a note! No one who can sing who has smog in his throat. And so,” said the Lorax, “Please pardon my cough, they cannot live here, so I'm sending them off. Where will they go? I don't hopefully know, they may escape to fly for a month, or a year to escape from the smog, you've smogged up around here. What's more!” snapped the Lorax, his dander was up, “let me say a few words about gluppity-glupp. Your machine chugs on day and night without stop, making gluppity-glupp also schloppity-schlopp. And what do you do with this left over goo? I'll show you, you dirty old Once-ler man you!”
question: Where will they go::: And what do you do with this left over goo

speaker: parent
content: “Your glumping the pond, where the humming-fish hummed. No more can they hum for their gills are all gummed. So I'm sending them off. Oh, their future is dreary. They'll walk on their fins, and they'll get woefully weary in search of some water that isn't so smeary.”

speaker: parent
content: And then I got mad, I got terribly mad. I yelled at the Lorax, "Now listen here dad! All you do is yap-yap, and say bad! Bad! Bad..."

speaker: child
content: Why did he call him dad?
question: Why did he call him dad

speaker: parent
content: 'cause he's acting like a father, by telling him what to do, and he doesn't like it.

speaker: parent
content: "Well, I have my rights sir, and I'm telling you I intend to go on doing just what I do. And for your information, you Lorax, I'm figuring on biggering, and biggering, and biggering, and BIGGERING, turning more truffula trees into thneeds which everyone, everyone, EVERYONE needs!”

speaker: parent
content: And at that very moment, we heard a loud WHACK, from outside in the fields came a sickening smack of an axe on a tree, then we heard the tree fall. The very last truffula tree of them all. No more trees, no more thneeds, no more work to be done. So, in time my uncles, and aunts, everyone all waved me goodbye. They jumped into my cars, and drove away under the smoke-smuggered stars. Now all that was left the bad smelling sky, was my big empty factory, the Lorax, and I. The Lorax said nothing, just gave me a glance, just gave me a very sad, sad backwards glance as he lifted himself by the seat of his pants. And I'll never forget the grim look on his face, when he heisted himself, and took leave of this place through a hole in the smog without leaving a trace. And all that the Lorax left here, is this mess, was a small pile of rocks, with the one word unless.

speaker: parent
content: Whatever that meant. Well, I just couldn't guess. That was long, long ago, but each day since that day, I've sat here and worried, and worried, and worried away, through the years while my buildings have fallen apart, I've worried about it with all of my heart. “But now,” said the Once-ler, "now that you're here, the word of the Lorax seemed perfectly clear. Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better, it's not! So, “Catch!,” calls the Once-ler, he lets something fall, “It's a truffula seed, it's the last one of all.”

speaker: parent
content: What are you doing?
question: What are you doing

speaker: parent
content: “You're in charge of the last of the truffula seeds, and the truffula trees are what everyone needs. Plant a new truffula, treat it with care. Give it clean water, and feed it fresh air. Grow a forest, protect it from axes that hack. Then the Lorax, and all of his friends may come back.” The end.
